item.title: Why Victory Day in Russia is different this year
item.description: The invasion of Ukraine means that fewer Russian tanks and other military hardware will rumble through Moscow's Red Square on Monday, when the country marks its victory over Nazi Germany in the Second World War. The patriotic fervor associated with the sacred holiday, however, could be as strong as ever.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Russian T-72 tanks during a rehearsal for the Victory Day military parade in St. Petersburg, Russia, on May 5, 2022. (Dmitri Lovetsky / AP)

item.title: New evidence found in Madeleine McCann case as German prosecutor is 'sure' suspect killed British girl
item.description: A German prosecutor has said he is 'sure' that Madeleine McCann -- the British girl who disappeared from a resort in Portugal in 2007 at the age of three -- was killed by suspect Christian Bruckner.
item.dc:creator: CNN
item.enclosure: A candle burns next to a photo of Madeleine McCann in Praia da Luz, Portugal, on May 3 2017. (Armando Franca / AP)

item.title: Queen to miss traditional royal garden party season
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II will miss the traditional royal garden party season, where she would normally meet with hundreds of people on the grounds of her residences in London and Edinburgh, palace officials said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Queen Elizabeth II during an audience at Windsor Castle, on April 28, 2022. (Dominic Lipinski / Pool Photo via AP)

item.title: U.S. announces seizure of superyacht owned by Russian oligarch
item.description: A superyacht that American authorities say is owned by a Russian oligarch previously sanctioned for alleged money laundering has been seized by law enforcement in Fiji, the U.S. Justice Department announced Thursday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: A view of the superyacht Amadea docked at the Queens Wharf in Lautoka, Fiji, on April 13, 2022. (Leon Lord / Fiji Sun via AP)

item.title: Karine Jean-Pierre to be next White House press secretary
item.description: U.S. President Joe Biden on Thursday named Karine Jean-Pierre to be the next White House press secretary, the first Black woman and openly LGBTQ person to serve in the role, with incumbent Jen Psaki set to leave the post next week.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: White House deputy press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre speaks at a press briefing at the White House in Washington, Friday, July 30, 2021. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

item.title: An Alabama inmate and a corrections officer are missing. Here's what we know
item.description: Authorities in Alabama are searching for a corrections officer and an inmate who is charged with murder after they went missing last Friday. The two, who officials said are not related but may have had a romantic relationship, have not been seen since. Here's what we know so far.
item.dc:creator: CNN
item.enclosure: Composite image shows Casey Cole White, left, and Assistant Director of Corrections Vicky White. (U.S. Marshals Service, Lauderdale County Sheriff's Office via AP)

item.title: Israeli medics say 3 killed in stabbing attack near Tel Aviv
item.description: A pair of Palestinian attackers went on a stabbing rampage in a town near Tel Aviv on Thursday night, killing at least three people and wounding four others before fleeing in a vehicle, Israeli authorities said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Israeli forces secure the area of a stabbing attack in the town of Elad, Israel, Thursday, May 5, 2022. (AP Photo/Maya Alleruzzo)

item.title: DND says review exonerates Canada's mission in Ukraine of training extremists
item.description: The Department of National Defence says it has concluded its 2021 review into the findings of a report from George Washington University that alleged Canadian Armed Forces trained Ukrainian soldiers who belong to extremist groups and found itself absolved.
item.dc:creator: Christy Somos
item.enclosure: A photo posted in 2019 to Centuria’s Telegram shows a group of uniformed men posing next to one of the buildings of the Ukrainian National Army Academy. The building is part of the NAA’s campus in Lviv. It is possible that Centuria’s manipulation of the original photo included a modification that changed the banner in the resulting image to feature a Sonnenkreuz as opposed to a symbol reminiscent of crosshairs on a target, according to the report. (Oleksiy Kuzmenko/George Washington University IEREs/Military Order Centuria/Telegram)

item.title: Cardinal: Pope OK'd spending 1M euros to free kidnapped nun
item.description: Pope Francis authorized spending up to 1 million euros to free a Colombian nun kidnapped by al-Qaida-linked militants in Mali, a cardinal testified Thursday, revealing previously secret papal approval to hire a British security firm to find the nun and secure her freedom.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Colombian nun Gloria Cecilia Narvaez is escorted by police after her arrival at El Dorado airport in Bogota, Colombia, Tuesday, Nov. 16, 2021. (AP Photo/Leonardo Munoz)

item.title: U.S. Senate to vote next week on protecting abortion rights
item.description: The U.S. Senate will vote next week on legislation that would codify abortion rights into federal law as Democrats mount their response to the Supreme Court's leaked draft decision that would overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer speaks to reporters at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 3, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)
